Posts.Content: Hi Suzie, the advice from Littleone is good. Unfortunately it is difficult to know what to do to prepare. I did extra exercise, both before and after, lots and lots of walking, as I’d heard it helps to push it all through quickly. That didn’t work, so I tried adding fasting to the exercise regime, for two days beforehand just drinking lots of water and a little fruit, that didn’t work either. For the next cycle, I rested, ate normally, drank loads and loads of water (essential in all of this) and although I was still very poorly, I was no worse! I think chemo is so intense that little changes just won’t affect it. Whatever SEs you get, be sure to write them down by numbered day, show them to the onc at your appt and they will know what is happening, why and how to help.  In terms of prep, an ’extra soft’ toothbrush is essential, along with a mild toothpaste. Hand gel and wipes, (although it is proven that many infections through chemo start from our natural, internal bacteria), lots of comfies, PJs, slippers and dressing gowns, magazines, puzzle books or your iPad for chemo sessions, crackers and dry biscuits for nausea. In terms of food, I bought pineapple and on my 2nd cycle, even the smell of it made me heave. We spent a fortune on food, as it is similar to being pregnant, with cravings that can’t be satisfied. I used to send poor Dec to the 24 hour ASDA at 11pm for something like cream soda or Ryvita crackers, I’d eat or drink it, then within 24 hours, even the thought of it made me heave again. Don’t stock up on any food stuff until you know what you like. I turned to Knorr Chicken noodle soup when I felt poorly and ginger beer helped too. We are all so, so different and until you are well into your chemo, it is an unknown. Good luck with it all and just smile when you can. Life comes back after all this and somehow, this horrible, vile experience makes it all feel better than it was before. We are here if you need us and you can PM me if you like. Good luck, xxx.

I have an acknowledged increased risk of RT but they have carefully gone through the science and stats and persuaded me that it is worth carrying on and finishing this final, relatively easy stage of the treatment. I am sure, like all of us, that you don't want this to come back and you know that you need to throw everything they offer at it! If I can do this, you can too. Posts.Content: Hi Minsky and Unicorn12, please don’t sit there worrying. This disease takes enough from you, without adding to it. Chemo is different for everyone, some are poorly, some have very minor side effects. If you are one of those that feels poorly, your team will look after you. Whatever happens, you will be amazed at how quickly the time passes and before you know it, it all seems like a bad dream. Just take it one day at a time and keep busy. Plan to have support around you, help with cleaning and cooking, especially if you have a family to care for. Plan to let things ‘slide’! Don’t attempt to keep things perfectly normal, as that just won’t happen. This is big and scary, but it is soooo doable! Chemo is hard, but the results can be amazing and it is all worth it in the end. Good luck both of you. If you need a shoulder, try the AWAKE thread, started by LondonLass. Posts.Content: Hi Harridamen, I was the same, HER2+ and lymph nodes. My lymph nodes on the other side were also 'reactive' and 'palpable'. They didn't seem to think this was a concern so I looked it up, (I still have access to all the published medical docs and journals from a prev job in the science world, so not Dr Google). They can't be sure as to why, but they don't publish unless they have evidence to show it happens. I think it may just be our body's fighting mechanism is strong; it knew something was wrong and the lymphs on the other side were reacting even though the cancer cells were not in that area. I finished chemo in December, 2 days of Herceptin, Pertuzumab, Carboplatin and Docetaxel and the pathology from my mastectomy and ANC in late January showed no cancer at all! Good luck. Posts.Content: Hi Harridamen, much of the advice I'd give is said above, but one thing that my sisters thanked me for was how I spoke to their daughters for them. They are 5, 7, 10 and 13. The eldest understood much of what was happening, but I didn't want the babies to be scared when they saw me looking poorly. I sat the 2 youngest down and told them that I had a germ inside me and that the medicine I needed to kill it would make me and the germ feel really poorly. I wanted them to know that the medicine was what made my hair fall out and made me ill, it was not the germ, so that they understood that when the medicine stopped, the germ would be dead and I'd get better again. I remember when I was 12-13 and my uncle had cancer. To me, his symptoms, the hair loss, the sickness etc were terrifying! I thought it was the cancer doing that and I felt there was no hope. I didn't understand that it was the chemo and I really wanted the children to not be as frightened as I had been. It worked and they were all fine. I know it is different as they are not my children, but it is an approach. I also just want to refer to a couple of points above. Toxophilite mentioned how evil Dr Google can be and she is so right. However, she isn't saying 'don't find out more' she is just saying be wary of untrusted websites. Macmillan, BreastCancerUK and BreastCancerResearchUK are all good sources of info and can be trusted to give you accurate information and do not resort to scaremongering. You don't need to live in ignorance and many of us understand the need to know more and how it helps us to cope. Just be careful where you get your information from and if in doubt, ask the forums on here. We are here whenever you need us. Xx

Posts.Title: Annoyed

Posts.Content: Hi Kimbeelou, the HER2 test comes back as HER2+, HER2++ or HER2+++. If it shows just one plus sign, this is a negative result, 2 plus signs is borderline and 3 plus signs is a positive result. It sounds like you might be borderline, as that is not a simple yes or no result. As for changes in diet and lifestyle, I haven’t drunk alcohol regularly and very rarely to excess, since I was 19. I drank around twice a year and even then just a few voddies. I have never smoked even one cigarette. I ate hardly any red meat and ate mostly chicken and fish and I was fit and healthy, an ideal BMI and did regular exercise. I still got a very aggressive, grade 3 cancer that had already advanced locally, even though I had had a clear breast exam just 5 months before! Some things, done to excess may well increase your risk, but the fact is that you have it now and if they can help to reduce that risk with proven medicine, would you refuse this? Herceptin (Trastuzumab) is a wonder drug and women worldwide have fought tooth and nail to get it, so if it is on offer, that is surely a good thing. I am allergic to Herceptin and have to have it by IV, via a drip bag over a couple of hours, with other drugs to reduce the side effects, but there’s no way I would let them stop administering it. Chemo was hard and made me so ill, but I got through 6 cycles and the cancer was obliterated. The mx and anc took part of me away, but the relief to know it was no longer inside me, but being sliced up in a lab somewhere was amazing. I am throwing everything I can at this. If I lose this fight, it will never be for lack of trying. This is scary and we don’t have the time to really think about what is happening, but our medical teams see this every day. They see what works and they know what to do to help. I think second opinions really help, but don’t let them delay the start of your treatment; this is your life after all! Good luck. Xx
